column4: i'm using the find to execute a command (lets say renaming the file) and it will put the new file in my home folder (or whatever folder i'm running the command from) is there a way to get it to save right where it is?
yes
what are you running exactly?
its to convert a bunch of jpegs i have in folders to bitmap and resize them..
ok
here is the command
let'ssee it :)
convert is from imagemagick
that 'cover.bmp' is the output filename, right?
correct, and that keeps overwriting itself in my home folder
so do this instead: find /media/ipod -name folder.jpg -exec convert {} -resize 125x125 125.{} \;
see the thing is, when i had album art they are all as folder.jpg , in about 800 different folders i want to save them back where they are.. as cover.bmp
ok, in that case, do this: find /media/ipod -name folder.jpg | while read x; do convert "$x" -resize 125x125 "$(dirname "$x")/cover.bmp"; done
try it on a small test directory first!
done is not included right
done closes the 'do'
ie. it's needed
oohh ok good thing i asked
works in the test dir! here goes the real thing! thanks
it'll even work for files/dirs with spaces in their names, unlike your -exec line
ooh nice catch, thanks.. wouldve been stuck on that for hours :(
that's what all the double quotes are for...
